prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote this situation is in the wrong. The scenario involves taking a 3-year-old to a fun activity while the partner is at work. The partner has been consistently giving excuses not to go out, and the author decided to go with a friend instead. The partner is upset because he can't join and wants to cancel the plans.

First, I need to consider the key points. The partner's excuses are about not wanting to go out, being tired, or not wanting to spend money, even though they can afford it. The author took initiative to do something the child would enjoy. The partner is now upset about not being included. 

Common themes in such situations often revolve around fairness and shared responsibility. The partner's excuses might indicate a lack of interest in spending quality time with the child, which could be a red flag. The author is trying to provide enrichment for their child, which is generally seen as a positive. The partner's reaction seems to be about his own feelings of exclusion rather than the child's needs. 

In terms of fairness, if the partner has been consistently uncooperative and the author made a choice based on the child's well-being, the author's actions are justified. The cost is minimal (£7 each), so money isn't a real issue. The partner's demand to cancel the plans might be self-centered. 

However, communication could be a factor. The author might have considered discussing plans more thoroughly, but given the partner's past behavior, it's understandable they acted independently. The core issue is the partner's lack of support for family activities, which isn't the author's fault. 

So, the author isn't in the wrong (B). The partner's behavior is the main issue here, not the author's decision to prioritize the child's happiness.
